text: hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new soft pink
truth record why do the heathen rage
this is the third full-length LP from
electronic music producer and singer
drew Daniel this is his on-again
off-again musical project the soft pink
truth you may actually be more likely to
have heard this man's work under the
name Matt mos the musical duo he has
been involved with with his significant
other Martin Schmidt for many years now
they've essentially built a name for
themselves with their incredibly
creative approach to sound craft namely
sampling having created songs with
samples from sperm and rhinoplasty among
other things the one of my favorites of
theirs happens to be a record that has
no samples on it whatsoever supreme
balloon and these guys also did have a
hand in creating one of my favorite
Bjork Records Vespertine but I have not
really been that crazy about their
output as of late I thought their last
full length LP was kind of mild maybe a
little unsurprising for them and I
thought that they're pretty ambitious
effort to collaborate with so percussion
on their 2010 album was just slightly
underwhelming however I think the
concept behind this new soft pink truth
record right here is a pretty bold
change of pace for drew it's a series of
black metal covers nine of them to be
exact with a quirky spoken word intro
and the originals on this record come
from a variety of different black metal
bands and the covers are executed in a
variety of different styles the artists
featured range from early black metal
pioneers like venom and hell hammer to
Norwegian black metal heavyweights
staples like dark throne and mayhem and
the whole record finishes off with a
cover of grim and frostbitten gaybar
attract from a sort of black metal
parody band the seth putnam of anal [ __ ]
had running in the early 2000s and
ironically this cover is maybe one of
the most authentic one of the most true
to sound when it comes to drew capturing
that old-school black metal flavor
because most of the time drew goes
completely off the stylistic map
on this thing going as far as to turn
some of these tracks into dance music
jams with female lead vocals or taking
the really gruesome campy nasty black
metal vocals style and throwing it over
some break beats or just some generally
funky electronics the whole thing the
whole aesthetic the whole idea reminds
me so much of that Dirty Projectors
record that came out a while ago that
Black Flag covers record rise above
similarly this soft pink truth record
seems to show very little concern for
anybody who might have grown up with
these songs and sees them as
unchangeable and sacred but non purest
fans of black metal I think they may
find a lot to love in in some of these
covers a lot of them are interesting
creative very colorful full of
personality surprising and many of them
do a lot to bring the lyrics forward and
make them more of a focus not really
obscuring the lyrics behind any kind of
wretched screaming or shouting
personally the tracks I enjoy the most
on this record are the ones that are
sort of truer to form like the venom
cover black metal even though the track
is electronic and it has sort of a
playful vibe to it
I do think soft pink truth brings
forward kind of a an industrially tinged
version of this really hard-hitting
black metal song I love what he does
with the chorus on this thing and even
though this track is quirky in a sense
it does have kind of a grim presentation
to it and there are other tracks on here
that I think are equally successful but
maybe a tad sillier like satanic black
devotion where in the middle of the song
as the track moves into a bit of an
electronic breakdown you get a sample of
I've got the power surprisingly though
this doesn't really ruin the vibe of the
track even as the song progresses away
from this really dark grim acoustic
intro the song beholding the throne of
Mike goes over really well too even
though much of its backing rhythms are
dance oriented the only times I really
get disappointed with the tracks on here
the feature does the nastier more
gruesome vocals are saito mattock rites
and buried by time and dust I don't
really mind that some of these tracks
are backed with vintage electronic music
grooves but just the tambour the weak
tambour and some of the dinky electronic
sound
on these tracks it feels like somebody's
trying to write me a really threatening
letter in comic sans going even further
down this road are the songs I mentioned
earlier that are essentially dance songs
with female lead vocals like let there
be bola frost and ready to [ __ ] the
latter of which I do like but let there
be bola frost instrumentally just feel
so generic and even though I'm not
totally head-over-heels for these tracks
I'm still kind of in awe of the ballsy
gutsy moves it took to remake these
songs like this which is actually kind
of how I feel about this entire record
in general some may definitely pull
their hair out over this record I might
to an extent if I had more and some may
definitely call this record the hipster
black metal apocalypse but I still think
this record is very fun it's
entertaining it's definitely perplexing
I'm feeling a strong 6 to Lite 7 on this
thing transition if you've given this LP
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's it
Anthony Fantana the soft pink truth
forever
